Relations with Turkey have become extremely fraught Turkey's currency plunged to
record lows after President Trump announced new tariffs on Turkish steel and
aluminum last week has contributed to
a deepening economic crisis for that country Turkish president to one said
yesterday that his country would boycott u.s.
Made electronic products and just today Turkey announced a half
a $1000000000.00 in retaliatory tariffs against American goods Amanda Sloat was
a senior Obama State Department official responsible for Turkey She's now
a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and I began with an economic question
for her asking why Turkey's economic problems seem to be reverberating around the
world the biggest challenge is the way that the Turkish economy is structured and
primarily that has to do with the fact that they are very dependent on foreign
investment coming in they are very dependent on their exports going out and they
are also very dependent on borrowing in dollars and why so when an economy is so
tied to the outside world when something happens medical anime I mean inevitably
it's going to affect elsewhere if they're leveraged in in dollars and so what we
see is that
a lot of large and medium sized companies have borrowed in dollars and so now that
there is
a significant depreciation of the lira against the dollar holding companies could
end up going bankrupt this could also have
a spillover effect on banks that are now holding bad loans what does the fact that
Turkey is in this mess right now say about heir to one and his style of not just
economic management but his style of leadership I mean there's one thing that it
indicates about his economic management which is his outdated belief that having
low interest rates leads to low inflation there's also
a lack of financial expertise in his cabinet he has appointed his son in law as the
economy minister so there is an effort on his part to try and centralize
a lot of power within the power. Now in this new presidential system that has come
into effect and that includes economic power and I think what we are seeing is that
while you can exert a lot of control over political forces in your country it is
a lot harder to try and control the economy especially given the linkages that it
has with the rest of the international market Hasn't this always been
a reality with the one at least in recent years that
a lot of Western powers don't necessarily love him he's not the partner they would
choose but they're sort of stuck with him because of Turkey's really important
place in the world I think that's right there was
a lot of high expectations when heir to one party came into power in 2000 to he was
seen as being much more Western oriented he was seen as being much more liberal
Turkey was seen as
a Muslim majority democracy that could be inspiring to countries in the Arab Spring
so there was a lot of optimism initially and
a belief by the West that this was somebody that they could work with this
certainly has changed over the last couple of years as Turkey has grown
increasingly authoritarian has made foreign policy decisions that Western countries
don't agree with you said this is a Muslim majority democracy where there was
a lot of optimism about the role that Turkey might play in an ideal world what sort
of role is that I think there has been
a lot of questions about whether or not Islam and democracy are compatible with one
another and so I think the fact that Turkey was functioning as a democracy had
a democratic government was giving people optimism that these things are compatible
and as we had countries transitioning from more authoritarian regimes to the
potential of democracy within the Arab Spring there was the hope that Turkey would
be able to serve as
a model for those countries that an example for what could be yeah I don't think
that what is happening in Turkey should necessarily be taken as
a comment on the in compatibility of Islam and democracy it's more
a comment on the increasingly authoritarian nature of the ones rule over the
country let me just ask you broadly I mean if people. Listen to this and they're
not entirely sure what to think of Turkey and why Turkey matters to you as
a veteran Turkey watcher what would you tell
a listener right now well Turkey for better or worse is
a NATO ally and the reality is that even if we find Turkey difficult to deal with
in NATO now it's going to be even harder to deal with Turkey if it is outside NATO
so it certainly is a challenging ally we certainly are going through
a very difficult patch in our relationship but the reality is that Turkey given
where it is located continues to play a significant role in terms of u.s.
Interests in the region not only Syria as we discussed but also future
counterterrorism challenges that are going to arise migration as I mentioned is
a significant issue for the Europeans as well as efforts to try and address other
challenges that we're seeing within the Middle East thank so much for coming in
thank you that's veteran Turkey watcher and former State Department official Amanda
